metadata.title: Thermal behavior of paraffin-nano-Al2O3 stabilized by sodium stearoyl lactylate as a stable phase change material with high thermal conductivity

Thermal behavior of paraffin-nano-Al2O3 stabilized by sodium stearoyl lactylate as a stable phase change material with high thermal conductivity

http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.renene.2015.11.043 0960-1481/© 2015 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t
A new kind of nano composite phase change material (NCPCM) was prepared using sodium stearoyl lactylate (SSL) as a surfactant to improve the dispersion of the Al2O3 nano-particles (with 2.5, 5, 7.5, and 10 wt.%) in paraffin with a SSL/Al2O3 mass ratio of 1:3.5. To evaluate the efficiency of the prepared PCMs, the melting rate of them at a temperature range of 50e60 C and the effective thermal conductivity values in the solid and liquid states at a temperature range of 25e75 C were measured using the k-type thermocouple and the transient hot wire technique, respectively. The heat storage behavior of the samples was investigated and their melting temperature, latent heat, and thermal reliability were determined using differential scanning calorimetry (DSC). Results showed that effective thermal conductivity enhancement ratios for the sample containing 10.0 wt.% nano-Al2O3 were 31% and 13% in the solid and liquid states, respectively, which are higher than those reported in similar studies. In addition, melting rate increased by 27%. As expected, all the PCMs showed good thermal reliability after 120 melting/freezing cycles. Based on our results, it may be concluded that the prepared PCMs can be regarded as effective heat storage materials for application in energy storage systems.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The escalating use of fossil fuels over the past 100 years has led to increasing greenhouse gas emissions giving rise to global warming. Many research efforts have, therefore, been directed toward finding appropriate methods for using renewable energy sources such as solar energy [1,2]. The main potential obstacle hindering the use of solar energy is its non-uniform and time dependent nature. Storing solar energy in thermal, chemical, or mechanical forms when its production or harvest exceeds the demand level seems to be a promising solution to overcome these problems [3e5]. Thermal energy storage as a latent heat of fusion in

phase change materials (PCMs) is one of the best energy storage methods because these materials have the potential to store a high amount of energy during their phase change process without large changes in volume at constant temperatures [1].
Such favorable properties as good stability, negligible supercooling, low cost, and especially good potential to store solar energy in the form of latent heat have made PCMs such as paraffin desirable for use in solar energy storage systems. However, they often have a low thermal conductivity which reduces their performance [6]. Therefore, heat transfer enhancement techniques such as increasing the heat transfer surface and thermal conductivity are required to increase the heat transfer rate of PCMs and to improve the efficiency of the storage system [2]. Thermal conductivity enhancement using expanded graphite [7e12], carbon fiber [13e16], metal matrix [17], Synthetic hybrid nanomaterials [18e23] and metal or metal oxide nanoparticles [24e29] has been widely studied by several researchers. PCM composites have been produced in a number of studies by dispersing metal or metal oxide nanoparticles as they offer a remarkable capability for enhancing
thermal conductivity at low volume fractions. The results have shown their considerable effects on increasing heat transfer rate [25e37]. Sahan et al. (2015) reported that the thermal conductivity of paraffin increased by 48% and 60% using 10% and 20% weight percentage of Fe3O4 nanoparticles respectively [38]. Fan and Khodadadi (2012) showed that addition of CuO nanoparticles to Cyclohexane-based PCMs resulted in enhanced thermal conductivity in both solid and liquid states [39]. Although many researchers have shown that increasing the volume fraction of nanoparticles increases the thermal conductivity of nanofluids [40e43], they reported that, at concentrations above 2%, thermal conductivity decreased in the solid state and its measured value was low compared to that associated with minor concentrations. In contrast to these results, Ho and Gao (2009) indicated that the thermal conductivity of paraffin with 5.0 and 10.0 wt.% of nanoAl2O3 increased by more than 2% and 6%, respectively, at a temperature of 30 C. Their results also showed that the thermal conductivity enhancement of the composites was a function of temperature [25]. Moreover, literature review shows that a linear relationship may or may not hold between volume fraction and thermal conductivity enhancement [40,44e48].
Despite the many studies carried out to investigate the thermal conductivity of nanocomposites and the numerous models proposed for its prediction [49e51], only a few investigations have dealt with the phase change properties of nanocomposites as latent heat storage materials. Ho and Gao (2009) reported that addition of alumina nanoparticles has a slight effect on the melting/freezing behavior of paraffin [25]. Fan et al. (2013) found that the phase change enthalpy of paraffin slightly decreased because of the presence of carbon nanofillers. However, their influence on the phase change temperatures was not significant [13]. Desgrosseilliers et al. (2013) investigated the phase change properties of the lauric acid and indicated that the onset of the melting temperature and the heat of fusion of reagent grade and practical grade of lauric acid weren't significantly changed after 500 accelerated thermal cycles [52]. Wu et al. (2010) developed a nanofluid based PCM by dispersing Cu, Al and C/Cu nanoparticles in the paraffin using various dispersant. Their results showed that the little change was occurred in latent heat and phase-change temperature of PCMs after 100 thermal cycles [24]. Qian et al. (2015) prepared novel form-stable phase change materials using diatomite and three PCMs and showed that the prepared PCMs were thermally and chemically stable after a 200 phase change cycles [53]. Tumirah et al. (2014) indicated the good thermal reliability of the prepared nano encapsulated organic PCM after 360 heating/cooling cycles [54]. In other studies the changes of the latent heat and melting temperature after hundreds or thousands thermal cycles were investigated, but they are generally attributed to the PCMs without nanoparticles or the form stable PCMs [55e60]. Table 1 shows the summary of the studies about nano-paraffin composites in recent years.
Al2O3 nanoparticles have a good potential to improve the thermal conductivity of paraffin and they have cheap price as compared to such nanoparticles as Al, but like other nanoparticles they precipitate in organic solvents and lose their unique ability in thermal conductivity enhancement. Although precipitation is the major defect in their use in thermal energy storage systems, there are few studies about the preparation of a stable nano-Al2O3 composites along with thermal reliability and energy storage properties investigations after phase change cycles. So, the main objectives of the present work are: a) to prepare a stable phase change material with a high thermal conductivity for application in solar energy storage systems using sodium stearoyl lactylate as a surfactant (that isn't used before as a stabilizer in nanocomposite phase change materials), b) to investigate the phase change temperature, heating
rate, latent heat, and effective thermal conductivity of the material thus produced in the solid and liquid states and c) to investigate the thermal reliability of the samples after phase change cycles.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text:
Paraffin with a melting temperature in the range of 54e58 C was used as the phase change material (Merck, Germany), and nanoAl2O3 (Tecnan Co. Ltd., Spain) with an average particle size in the range of 10e20 nmwith the specifications shown in Table 2 was utilized to improve paraffin thermal performance.
Sodium stearoyl lactylate (SSL) was used as the surfactant for better dispersion of nanoparticles.
The chemical structure of SSL is shown in Fig. 1.

sections.heading: 2.2. Sample preparation
sections.text: Nanocomposite PCMs with different mass ratios of nano-Al2O3 were prepared using the following steps: firstly, the required quantity of paraffinwax with a melting temperature in the range of 54e58 C was weighed out using an electronic balance with an accuracy of ±0.0001 g. SSL and nano-Al2O3 (2.5, 5.0, 7.5, and 10.0 wt.%) with a mass ratio of 1:3.5 were added to melted paraffin in order to prepare the required nanocomposite. Magnetic stirring was used for nearly 1 h to disperse the nanoparticles throughout the PCM. A vacuum pump (VDE 0530, KNF NEUBERGER, INC., USA) was utilized (600 mmHg vacuum) to prevent the formation of air bubbles during magnetic stirring, because they can considerably decrease the thermal conductivity of the nanocomposites. Next, ultrasonic vibration was used for 2 h at 80 W and 50 kHz to ensure uniform distribution of the Al2O3 nanoparticles in the base fluids (1200 M, SONICA, Italy). Prior to this stage, an appropriate quantity of petroleum ether was added as a solvent to the samples to maintain the liquid form of the mixture during the process. Finally, the mixture was slightly heated to remove the residual solvent. The sedimentation photographs of PCMs after 48 h is shown in Fig. 2. As can be seen in this figure the prepared PCMs show good stability after this period.

sections.heading: 2.3. Determination of PCM thermal properties
sections.text: In order to investigate the effect of Al2O3 nanoparticles on the thermal behavior of paraffin, the properties of the prepared PCMs including heating and melting rate, effective thermal conductivity, phase change temperature, latent heat, and thermal reliability were determined using a k-type thermocouple, a transient hot-wire, and the differential scanning calorimetry (DSC). The measured values were then compared with those recorded for paraffin. All measurements were performed in duplicate.

sections.heading: 2.3.1. Heat storage behavior and thermal reliability properties of the PCMs
sections.text:
A differential scanning calorimeter (DSC) equipped with a cooling attachment containing liquid nitrogen (SANAF, Iran) was used both to study the energy storage properties of the PCMs, including phase change temperatures and latent heat, and to determine their thermal reliability after undergoing melting/ freezing cycles. Before DSC measurements, the samples were placed in incubators with temperatures controlled at 20 C (WIR150, WiseCube, Korea) and 70 C (UFB 400, Memmert, Germany) alternately at time intervals of 1 h to undergo melting/freezing cycles. After 0, 40, 60, 80, 100, and 120 melting/freezing cycles, 5e6 mg of each sample was placed into the sample cells and put
into the DSC instrument. Measurements were performed for pure paraffin and the paraffin-nano-Al2O3 composites (2.5, 5, 7.5, and 10 wt.%) at a heating rate of 5 C/min and over a temperature range of 20e90 C. Finally, the thermal properties of the prepared PCMs were determined and compared with those of pure paraffin.

sections.heading: 2.3.2. Heating rate
sections.text: Since addition of nanoparticles affects the effective thermal conductivity of paraffin, the heat transfer properties and consequently the heating rate of prepared PCMs are also affected. To investigate the effect of nano-Al2O3 on the heating rate of the PCMs, a k-type thermocouple was fixed at the center of a test tube to measure temperature changes during the heating process. The accuracy of the temperaturemeasurement was ±0.1 C. The test tubes were filledwith themelted PCMs and left at a constant temperature of 25 C for the samples to solidify before they were immediately subjected to the heating process in a water bath (WNB 14, Memmert, Germany) at a constant temperature of 70 C. A digital recorder (R3100, Supcon, China) was used to record temperature at time intervals of half a second during heating and the rate of its change in the nanocomposite PCMs with different mass ratios of nano-Al2O3 was compared with that of pure paraffin. The experimental set up used for heating rate evaluation is shown in Fig. 3.

sections.heading: 2.3.3. Effective thermal conductivity
sections.text:
The transient hot wire technique was employed to measure the thermal conductivities of both pure paraffin and the paraffin-nanoAl2O3 composites in the solid and liquid states at a temperature range of 25e75 C. Initially, the hot wire probe was placed at the center of the cubes (1 cm in thickness and 5 cm in length) which had been filled with the melted composites. Then, the samples were left at room temperature to solidify. Next, the cubes were put into the controlled temperature incubator to reach the desired temperature. Current intensity and temperatureetime data were continuously collected using a multimeter (DT830B, Zhanzhou Weihua Electronics, China) and a digital recorder (Datalogger R3100, Supcon, China), respectively, after connecting the probe heater to a DC power supply. The accuracy of the current and temperature measurements was ±0.1 mA and ±0.1 C, respectively. Effective thermal conductivity (W/m C) was calculated using the following equation:

sections.heading: 2.4. Statistical analysis
sections.text: Analysis of variance on the data was carried out using the SAS statistical software release 9 (SAS Institute, Cray, NC).

sections.heading: 3.1. Heat storage behavior and thermal reliability properties of the PCMs
sections.text: Melting temperature and phase change enthalpy, as well as thermal properties stability are important factors in PCMs that affect their efficiency in energy storage systems. In this study, differential scanning calorimetry was, therefore, used to investigate the thermal reliability of the prepared PCMs (i.e., the stability of thermal properties (melting temperature and phase change enthalpy)) after alternating melting/freezing cycles that PCMs are usually subjected to in solar heat storage systems and the influence of nano-Al2O3 on the melting temperature and phase change latent heats.

sections.heading: 3.1.1. Latent heat and phase change temperatures
sections.text:
Typical DSC thermograms of the pure paraffin and paraffinnano-Al2O3 composites are presented in Fig. 4. The first peak on the DSC curves represents the solidesolid phase transition, while the second one corresponds to the solideliquid phase change. Clearly, the onset and peak values of the solideliquid phase changes are almost 53 and 60 C, respectively, and the phase change occurs over a wide temperature range. Results show that the phase change peaks in the paraffin and composites with different loading levels of nanoparticles have relatively similar shapes and peak values.
The melting temperatures (Tm) and latent heats (L) of pure paraffin and composites at different nanoparticle concentrations are presented in Table 3. Latent heat was obtained by numerical integration of the total area under the solidesolid and liquidesolid phase change peaks. As can be seen in Table 3, the melting temperatures of the composites containing 2.5, 5.0, 7.5, and 10.0 wt.% nano-Al2O3 were, respectively, 1.20, 1.50, 1.35, and 1.65 C higher than those of pure paraffin. No significant differences were
observed between the liquidesolid phase change temperatures of paraffin and paraffin-nano-Al2O3 composites (a ¼ 0.01 (The probability of committing a Type I error is called the significance level, and is often denoted by a)).
As expected, the values for the latent heat of the composites were lower than those for pure paraffin. Moreover, they were reduced by increasing the mass fraction of nanoparticles so that decreases of 4.13, 5.41, 14.86, and 22 kJ/kg were observed for PCMs composed of 2.5, 5.0, 7.5, and 10.0 wt.% nanoparticles, respectively. The latent heat capacity of PCMs can be calculated by multiplying the latent heat value and the mass fraction of pure paraffin. The calculated values were similar to the experimental data obtained from DSC curves (results not shown). Adding a non-melting material in a PCM reduces the enthalpy in the same percentage.
These results show that the phase change temperature and heat storage capacity of paraffin were not significantly influenced by nano-Al2O3 addition up to 5% (a ¼ 0.01). However, high loading levels of the nanoparticles resulted in reduced heat storage capacity due to an increase in the replacement of paraffin wax with nanoparticles that do not undergo phase change and, consequently at equal amounts, they can absorb less energy in their phase transition compared to the samples containing 2.5 and 5.0 wt.% nanoAl2O3.
Ho and Gao (2009) also obtained DSC curves with similar shapes for prepared PCMs containing 5% and 10 wt.% nano-Al2O3. They concluded that the nanoparticles addition doesn't have noticeable effect on the phase change temperatures, but the addition of 5% and 10 wt.% nanoparticles into paraffin reduces the PCMs latent heat of fusion more than 7% and nearly 13% respectively [25]. Wang et al. (2010) indicated that the melting temperature and latent heat of fusion of paraffin wax are reduced due to the addition of Al2O3 nanoparticles [41].

sections.heading: 3.1.2. Thermal reliability of the PCMs
sections.text:
The PCMs containing 2.5, 5.0, 7.5, and 10.0 wt.% Al2O3 nanoparticles were used to investigate the thermal reliability of the samples after 0, 40, 60, 80, 100, and 120 melting/freezing cycles. Table 4 and Fig. 5 show the solideliquid phase-change temperatures (Tm) and the latent heat (L) of PCMs, respectively, as a function of cycle numbers.
The change ratios of latent heat (100 (Lt L0)/L0) and melting temperature (100 (Tmt Tm0)/Tm0) (the ratio of each factor after a special meltingefreezing cycle difference with its initial to initial value) are presented in Table 5.
As shown in Table 5, the greatest change observed in melting temperature was 5.06%, which was not significant (a ¼ 0.01) and attributed to the sample containing 2.5 wt.% nano-Al2O3 subjected to 100 thermal cycles. In addition, although increasing nanoparticle loading from 5.0% to 10.0% resulted in a significant decrease in the latent heat of the PCMs, the effect of thermal cycles on latent heat was negligible (a¼ 0.01) and the maximum change observed in the latent heat was 4.31%, which was attributed to the sample containing 2.5 wt.% nano-Al2O3 after 120 thermal cycles. So, it may be concluded that addition of nanoparticles had no noticeable effect on the melting/freezing behavior of the PCMs, and that paraffinnano-Al2O3 composites had a good thermal reliability after thermal cycles. Hence, all the prepared PCMs are suitable for use in energy storage systems from the standpoint of thermal reliability. Sahan et al. (2015) showed that the mean storage capacity after 100, 200, 300, 400 and 500 melting/freezing cycles was approximately similar to the uncycled sample and changed only 1.4% [38].
However DSC analysis after alternate thermal cycles, don't provide evidences about stability of PCMs. Even sedimentation has happened; the measured melting point would not have significant changes because it will only change upon chemical decay of paraffin that is apparently not occurred after 120 thermal cycles. The measured latent heat of fusion would also not change with sedimentation because it is an intensive property.

sections.heading: 3.2. Heating rate
sections.text:
Fig. 6 shows the heating curves for paraffin and the four PCMs prepared with 2.5, 5.0, 7.5 and 10.0 wt.% nano-Al2O3. It can be seen that addition of Al2O3 nanoparticles significantly increased the heating rates of the composites as compared to pure paraffin. The heating times for paraffin samples with 0, 2.5, 5.0, 7.5 and 10.0% nano-Al2O3 to reach 70 C were 678, 662, 556, 532, and 492s, respectively.
Compared to the heating time of pure paraffin, total heating times significantly reduced by 2,18, 21 and 27% as a result of adding 2.5, 5.0, 7.5, and 10.0 wt.% nano-Al2O3, respectively (a ¼ 0.01).
Since the thermal behavior of phase change materials in their melting temperature ranges is very important for energy storage systems, we investigated the melting rate enhancements gained with the prepared PCMs at a temperature range of 50e60 C which represents the approximate onset and peak values of the solideliquid phase change (based on DSC thermograms) in order to gain a better understanding of the effects of nanoparticle additions on the thermal properties of composites. The results showed reductions in melting times of 9, 20, 24, and 27% for 2.5, 5.0, 7.5, and 10.0 wt.% nano-Al2O3 composites, respectively, as compared to pure paraffin, indicating that heat transfer rate in the composites increased as a function of nanoparticle mass fraction and the effect of nanoparticles addition is severe in melting temperature range. Arasu et al. (2011) indicated that the addition of 1% nano-Al2O3 leads to 4.8% increase in melting rate of paraffin wax and consequently enhance the heat transfer performance [72].
The observed increase in heating rate at temperature ranges of 25e70 C and 50e60 C is due to the effective thermal conductivity enhancement of composites as a result of nanoparticle addition that leads to significant increases in the heat transfer rates of PCMs. This will be taken up in the section below.

sections.heading: 3.3. Effective thermal conductivity
sections.text:
Thermal conductivity is one of the most important thermal properties of PCMs that has a considerable role in the rate of energy storage/release in both solid and liquid states. The measured values for effective thermal conductivity of both pure paraffin and paraffin-nano-Al2O3 composites as a function of temperature are presented in Fig. 7. As expected, the presence of nanoparticles had a significant influence on the effective thermal conductivity enhancement of the PCMs.
It can be seen that the effective thermal conductivity of the paraffin-nano-Al2O3 composites increased with nano-Al2O3 mass fraction. The highest effective thermal conductivity was attributed
to PCMs containing 10.0 wt.% nano-Al2O3 at 35 C and 55 C. At these same temperatures, the effective thermal conductivity of paraffin increased from 0.20 to about 0.28 and 0.29 W/m C (i.e., an enhancement of more than 43%). The observed enhancement is much higher than that obtained in similar studies [25,41]. The smallest effective thermal conductivity enhancement was attributed to the sample containing 2.5% nano-Al2O3 and was about 1% at 65 C that is not significant (a ¼ 0.01). Xie et al. (2002) investigated the thermal conductivity of Al2O3 nanofluids and indicated that the thermal conductivity of the suspensions is enhanced with increasing nanoparticles concentration [73]. Ho and Gao (2009) indicated that the increasing the temperature from 30 to 60 leads to an increase of more than 17% in thermal conductivity of paraffin based PCMs containing 10% nano-Al2O3 [25].
Table 6 presents the average values for effective thermal conductivity of composites and pure paraffin in solid and liquid states. The average values of effective thermal conductivity for pure paraffinwere 0.20W/m C in the solid state and 0.15W/m C in the liquid state. Compared to pure paraffin, the nano-Al2O3 composite (with a mass fraction of 10% that has the greatest influence on heat transfer enhancement) exhibited higher thermal conductivities by 0.06 and 0.02 W/m C at solid and liquid states, respectively.
On the other hand, as can be seen in Fig. 7, the effective thermal conductivity of paraffin-nano-Al2O3 composites depended on temperature in both solid and liquid states, increasing to a great extent at 35 and 55 C. According to the DSC curves, the onset temperatures of solidesolid and liquidesolid phase changes were around 35 and 53 C; hence, the effective thermal conductivity enhancement at these temperatures can be expected. In fact, the enhanced effective thermal conductivity at 35 C may be attributed to the change in the crystalline structure of the composite and the absorption of latent heat of the solidesolid phase change at this temperature [13]. In addition, effective thermal conductivity increases at 55 C due to the effect of temperature that changes the orderly solid structure of the composites and the resulting increase in themolecular vibration. Turning the orderly solid structure into a disorderly one results in a fall in the effective thermal conductivity of composites when the PCMs turn into the liquid state. These observations are in good agreement with those reported in similar studies on the thermal conductivity of nanofluids [28,42,74e76].
In order to clarify the effect of nanoparticle addition on heat transfer performance, effective thermal conductivity enhancement ratios of PCMs, i.e., the ratio of nanocomposite PCMs' effective thermal conductivity difference with its base fluid to the effective thermal conductivity of the base fluid (k k0/k0), were calculated both as a function of temperature and mass fraction as shown in Figs. 8 and 9, respectively.
It can be seen in Figs. 8 and 9 that nanoparticle additions led to 1e43% increases in the effective thermal conductivity of paraffin depending on nanoparticle concentration and temperature. The effective thermal conductivity enhancement ratio of nanocomposite PCMs containing 2.5% nano Al2O3 at 45 C, 65 C and
75 C and 5% nano Al2O3 at 75 C was not significant (a ¼ 0.01). For PCMs containing 10.0 wt.% nano-Al2O3, the effective thermal conductivity enhancement ratios were 31% and 13% in the solid and liquid states, respectively. The ordered structure of the solid state relative to that of the liquid state was able to enhance heat transfer between the nanoparticles and the paraffin. Thus, as shown above, effective thermal conductivity enhancement ratio was greater in the solid state than in the liquid state. As discussed in the last section, nanoparticles addition has the severe effect on heating rate at the melting temperature ranges (i.e. 50e60 C), that is because of the higher effective thermal conductivity enhancement at these temperatures as can be seen clearly from Figs. 7e9. In addition results indicate that in contrast to the findings of Ho and Gao (2009) [25] effective thermal conductivity enhancement appears to be nonlinear with an increase in the mass fraction of nano-Al2O3 in both the solid and liquid states and increases as the nanoparticle concentration increases. Moreover, the curves obtained for
different temperatures in the solid state are almost parallel, indicating that the influence of mass fraction on effective thermal conductivity enhancement was independent from the temperature effect.
The higher thermal conductivity enhancement ratios that have been obtained in this work, as compared to those reported in similar studies may be attributed to the presence of SSL as a dispersant to provide an uniform dispersion of nanoparticles in the PCM. Also, using a vacuum pump to prevent the formation of air bubbles in the nanocomposites during magnetic stirring has a strong effect on obtaining higher thermal conductivities so that the measured values obtained in the absence of a vacuum pump were considerably lower than those obtained when a vacuum pump was used (results not shown).

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: In this study, Al2O3 nanoparticles were employed to enhance the thermal performance of paraffin. Using SSL as a surfactant, a series of stable and homogenous paraffin-based composite PCMs with 2.5, 5.0, 7.5, and 10.0 wt.% nano-Al2O3 were prepared to study their thermal behavior. The results showed that the effective thermal conductivity of the PCMs thus prepared increased by increasing nano-Al2O3 mass fraction, exhibiting a nonlinear relationship with mass fraction in both the solid and liquid states. The highest effective thermal conductivity enhancement ratio was attributed to the nanocomposite containing 10.0 wt.% nano-Al2O3 at 35 C. Generally, the composites exhibited higher thermal conductivities at 35 and 55 C, which are near the phase change temperatures, than at other temperatures investigated. The effective thermal conductivity in the solid state was found to be higher due to the ordered structure of the composites than that in the liquid state. Furthermore, the heating rates of PCMs during the melting process increased significantly using Al2O3 nanoparticles due to the enhanced effective thermal conductivity. For composites containing 10.0 wt.% nano-Al2O3, the heating andmelting times reduced by 27%. The prepared PCMs showed good thermal reliability after 120 melting/freezing cycles and exhibited slight changes in their latent heat and phase-change temperature. Thus, addition of Al2O3 nanoparticles was able to improve the thermal conductivity of paraffin without any significant effects on its thermal properties. Based on our results, it may be concluded that, despite their higher thermal conductivities and their capability to achieve considerable reductions in heating times compared to pure paraffin, the samples containing 7.5 and 10% nano-Al2O3 exhibit lower performance levels in practical energy storage applications due to their lower amount of energy stored during phase change. Although it may be useful to find the optimum concentration considering the effect of each nano-Al2O3 loading level on thermal conductivity, latent heat, phase change temperature and thermal reliability, but generally it can be concluded that the prepared PCMs could be recommended as effective heat storage materials for energy storage applications because they have improved heat transfer rate without large change in their thermal stabilities and properties.

metadata.abstractText: A new kind of nano composite phase change material (NCPCM) was prepared using sodium stearoyl lactylate (SSL) as a surfactant to improve the dispersion of the Al2O3 nano-particles (with 2.5, 5, 7.5, and 10 wt.%) in paraffin with a SSL/Al2O3 mass ratio of 1:3.5. To evaluate the efficiency of the prepared PCMs, the melting rate of them at a temperature range of 50e60 C and the effective thermal conductivity values in the solid and liquid states at a temperature range of 25e75 C were measured using the k-type thermocouple and the transient hot wire technique, respectively. The heat storage behavior of the samples was investigated and their melting temperature, latent heat, and thermal reliability were determined using differential scanning calorimetry (DSC). Results showed that effective thermal conductivity enhancement ratios for the sample containing 10.0 wt.% nano-Al2O3 were 31% and 13% in the solid and liquid states, respectively, which are higher than those reported in similar studies. In addition, melting rate increased by 27%. As expected, all the PCMs showed good thermal reliability after 120 melting/freezing cycles. Based on our results, it may be concluded that the prepared PCMs can be regarded as effective heat storage materials for application in energy storage systems. © 2015 Elsevier Ltd.
